newsitem.title: CHINA: China says copper concentrate supply normal.
newsitem.headline: China says copper concentrate supply normal.

text.p: China's imports of copper concentrates have not been affected by problems plaguing overseas producers, industry officials said on Tuesday.
A strike at Canada's Inco smelter, now in its third week, coupled with heavy rain and landslides in Chile, have added to the market's bullish sentiment.
"There is no impact on us," an official of the China National Nonferrous Metals Import and Export Corp (CNIEC) said by telephone.
"The supply from Chile is normal," he said. China was expected to import 600,000-700,000 tonnes of copper concentrates from Chile, its biggest single supplier, in 1997.
The Inco strike and concentrate shipment delays in Papua New Guinea because of low water levels and fuel shortages have had no direct impact on CNIEC's imports, a second company official said.
The company has not placed buying orders with Inco and has no purchases from Papua New Guinea, she said.
"There is no impact on us, we have enough inventory for 1997," an official of the Jinlong Copper Smelter said by telephone from central Anhui province.

The smelter, a Sino-Japanese joint venture, needs to import all its copper concentrate. The company's annual demand for concentrate was estimated to reach 300,000-400,000 tonnes when it goes into full production, the official said.

The smelter began production last April and was considering exporting copper in the future, the official said, but declined to give further details. It has an annual production capacity of 100,000 tonnes.
